bestBHT.bht: Through faith, Abraham and Sarah, as good as dead, were blessed with descendants as numerous as the stars and the sand. This remarkable fulfillment, despite their advanced age and barrenness, shows that God's promises are not bound by human probabilities. It reminds the Jewish people of their incredible origin and the faith required to attain their position. Just as Abraham and Sarah became parents through faith, they too must rely on faith to uphold their heritage.

Henry Alford: Wonderful result of this faith of Abraham and Sarah.
Like the stars of the heaven in multitude.
Like the sand which is by the lip of the sea which is innumerable.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: "deadened"; no longer having, as in youth, energetic vital
Albert Barnes: The whole Jewish people sprang from one man, and...he was made the father and founder of a nation.
To human appearance there was no more probability, that he would have a son at that period of life, than that the dead would have.
The strength of faith in this case was, that there was simple confidence in God in the fulfillment of a promise where all human probabilities were against it.
John Calvin: Therefore even from one, and him in a like manner dead, there sprang so many as the stars."
If now the Jews are proud of their origin, let them consider what it was."
They cannot retain and defend the position they have acquired in any other way than by faith.
Philip Schaff: Wherefore also (a common Pauline expression) from one sprang there a race like the dust of the earth, the stars of the heaven, the sand on the lip of the sea, innumerable."
From a single, nay a lifeless, source sprang there a race like the dust of the earth, the stars of the heaven, the sand on the lip of the sea, innumerable."
Through faith Abraham became the father and Sarah the mother of them all.
Archibald T. Robertson: The perfect passive participle from νεκροω, late verb to make dead, to treat as dead (Romans 4:19), here by hyperbole.
'Along the lip of the sea' (from Genesis 22:17), χειλος here alone in this sense in the N.T.
Old compound verbal adjective (alpha privative and αριθμεω, to number), here alone in N.T.
John Gill: Therefore sprang there even of one... Isaac and Rebecca conceived in mind, and so there were born of one, Esau and Jacob.
And him as good as dead; being an hundred years of age...
So many as the stars of the sky in multitude, and as the sand which is by the sea shore innumerable; as was promised to Abraham...
John Wesley: As it were dead — Till his strength was supernaturally restored, which continued for many years after.

bhtAttempts.bht: Through faith, Abraham and Sarah, who were as good as dead, were blessed with descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and the sand on the seashore. The fulfillment of this promise was remarkable given their advanced age and barrenness. Their faith in God's word allowed them to become the parents of a great nation, the Jewish people, who trace their ancestry back to these individuals. This serves as a reminder that God's promises are not limited by human probabilities, and that the Jewish people should take pride in their incredible origin. It is through faith that they have attained their position, and it is through faith that they must continue to uphold it.

Through faith, Abraham and Sarah, as good as dead, were blessed with descendants as numerous as the stars and the sand. This remarkable fulfillment, despite their advanced age and barrenness, shows that God's promises are not bound by human probabilities. It reminds the Jewish people of their incredible origin and the faith required to attain their position. Just as Abraham and Sarah became parents through faith, they too must rely on faith to uphold their heritage.

Through faith, Abraham and Sarah, who were as good as dead, were blessed with descendants as numerous as the stars and the sand. This remarkable fulfillment, despite their advanced age and barrenness, shows that God's promises are not bound by human probabilities. The Jewish people should take pride in their incredible origin and acknowledge that their position can only be retained through faith. The faith of Abraham and Sarah serves as a powerful reminder that God's blessings transcend human limitations.

This remarkable fulfillment, despite their advanced age and barrenness, shows that God's promises are not limited by human probabilities. The Jewish people should take pride in their incredible origin and acknowledge that their position can only be retained through faith. The faith of Abraham and Sarah serves as a powerful reminder that God's blessings surpass human limitations.

Through faith, Abraham and Sarah, as good as dead, were blessed with descendants as numerous as the stars and the sand. Their advanced age and barrenness made the fulfillment of this promise seem improbable, but their unwavering faith in God allowed them to become the parents of a great nation. This serves as a powerful reminder that God's promises are not limited by human probabilities. The Jewish people can take pride in their incredible origin and must continue to uphold their position through faith.
